title: Selectors & Text: Hero Title + Lead + Emphasis (Interview Warm-up)

description.summary: Style a small hero header using BOTH element selectors and class selectors. Goal: set a clean base text style via element selectors, then override specific parts using classes (headline, tagline, highlight). This is a common interview check for basic selector targeting + readable typography.

arguments.name: Element selectors
arguments.desc: Use element selectors (h1, p) for base typography: font-size, color, line-height, and spacing.

arguments.name: Class selectors
arguments.desc: Use class selectors (.headline, .tagline, .highlight) to override specific elements without changing HTML structure.

arguments.name: Specificity (override correctly)
arguments.desc: Your class-based rules should override the element base styles where needed (e.g., .tagline overrides p color).

returns.desc: A hero header with consistent base paragraph styling, a distinct headline, and a highlighted word inside the tagline.

web.starterHtml:
Welcome to CSS Basics

CSS lets you style text, layouts, and more.

solutionBlock.overview: In interviews, the key check is: can you set sensible base typography with element selectors, then override specific parts with classes without fighting specificity. Here we style `h1` and `p` as the base, then use `.tagline` and `.highlight` for targeted overrides.

approaches.title: Approach — Base Elements + Targeted Class Overrides
approaches.prose: Use element selectors to create consistent defaults (sizes, margins, line-height). Then override the tagline color with a class and emphasize a single word using `.highlight`. This mirrors real UI work: base styles + small component overrides.
approaches.codeHtml:
Welcome to CSS Basics

CSS lets you style text, layouts, and more.

pitfalls: Only using classes and skipping element selectors defeats the point of the exercise.
Forgetting to reset default margins often causes unexpected spacing in real UIs.
If you style `p` color but never override `.tagline`, you miss the specificity/override practice.
techniques: Use element selectors for baseline typography and layout rhythm.
Use classes for component-level overrides and emphasis.
Keep overrides minimal so the cascade stays predictable.

title: Box Model: Margin, Padding, Border

description.summary: Build a simple card layout and practice the box model by using padding for inner spacing, margin for outer spacing, and border for outlines.

arguments.name: Padding
arguments.desc: Adds space inside the element between the content and the border.

arguments.name: Margin
arguments.desc: Adds space outside the element between it and neighboring elements.

arguments.name: Border
arguments.desc: Defines the outline edge of the element and helps visualize spacing.

returns.desc: A visually separated set of cards with internal padding, border outline, and equal spacing between cards.

solutionBlock.overview: This exercise demonstrates how the CSS box model affects layout and spacing. Padding adds inner breathing room, margins separate elements externally, and borders visually define boundaries.

approaches.title: Approach — Apply Padding, Border, and Margin
approaches.prose: Give each .card a padding for internal space, a subtle border for visibility, and a margin to separate multiple cards. Rounded corners make the design friendlier.

pitfalls: Forgetting that padding affects box size unless box-sizing is set to border-box.
Using only margin or padding for spacing makes it unclear which side creates the space.
techniques: Use padding for internal spacing, margin for separation between elements.
Add a border to make box boundaries visible when debugging layout issues.

body { font-family: system-ui, -apple-system, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin: 2rem; background: #fafafa; line-height: 1.6; }
.card { padding: 16px; border: 1px solid #ccc; border-radius: 8px; margin-bottom: 12px; background: #fff; }

title: Display & Centering: Center Inline Content

description.summary: Center a heading and a row of chip-like tags using inline/inline-block display and text alignment (no flex, no positioning).

arguments.name: text-align
arguments.desc: Use text-align: center on a parent to center inline/inline-block children as a group.

arguments.name: .tag { display: inline-block }
arguments.desc: Inline-block lets tags sit on one line while supporting padding and border radius.

arguments.name: Padding, radius, and spacing
arguments.desc: Use padding: 8px 12px; border-radius: 6px; and an 8px horizontal margin for consistent gaps.

returns.desc: A centered heading and a single line of evenly-spaced chip tags, centered as a group.

web.starterHtml:
Centered Content

HTMLCSSUI

solutionBlock.overview: Center inline content by setting `text-align: center` on a parent container. Make the chips `inline-block` so they can have padding and rounded corners, and space them with a small horizontal margin.

approaches.title: Approach — text-align Center + Inline-Block Chips
approaches.prose: Set `text-align: center` on `.chips` (or `.box`) to center all inline children as a group. Use `display: inline-block` on `.tag` to allow padding and border radius, and add `margin-right: 8px` (removed on the last tag) to create consistent gaps.
approaches.codeHtml:
Centered Content

HTMLCSSUI

pitfalls: Only inline-level content is centered by `text-align`. Blocks ignore it unless they are inline or inline-block.
Forgetting to remove the last chip’s right margin causes visual imbalance.
techniques: Use `inline-block` for chips to keep a single line while allowing padding and border radius.
`text-align: center` on the wrapper is a simple, widely supported centering method for inline content.

title: Positioning: Relative/Absolute Badge

description.summary: Add a small 'NEW' badge to the top-right corner of an image using relative and absolute positioning.

arguments.name: .product { position: relative }
arguments.desc: Make the container establish a local coordinate system for absolutely positioned children.

arguments.name: .badge { position: absolute; top/right }
arguments.desc: Place the badge relative to the nearest positioned ancestor (the product container).

arguments.name: Styling
arguments.desc: Add small padding, rounded corners, and a contrasting background to the badge.

returns.desc: A product image with a small badge pinned to its top-right corner that stays in place on scroll or resize.

examples: .badge { position: absolute; top: 8px; right: 8px; padding: 4px 8px; border-radius: 6px; background: #e63946; color: #fff; font-weight: 600; }

web.starterHtml: NEW

solutionBlock.overview: To pin a badge to a specific corner of an element, make the parent `.product` relatively positioned so it establishes a local coordinate system. Then, absolutely position the `.badge` in the top-right with a small offset and apply visual styles for clarity.

approaches.title: Approach — Relative Parent + Absolute Child
approaches.prose: Use `position: relative` on the `.product` container. This allows the `.badge` to be positioned absolutely within it. Apply `top` and `right` offsets to anchor the badge to the top-right corner. Add padding, border-radius, and a red background for visibility.
approaches.codeHtml: NEW
approaches.codeCss: .product { position: relative; display: inline-block; }\n.badge { position: absolute; top: 8px; right: 8px; padding: 4px 8px; border-radius: 6px; background: #e63946; color: #fff; font-weight: 600; letter-spacing: 0.5px; }\nimg { display: block; max-width: 100%; border-radius: 8px; }

pitfalls: If `.product` isn’t positioned relatively, `.badge` will be placed relative to the entire page.
Avoid using large pixel offsets that break responsive behavior.
techniques: Relative positioning on the parent establishes a local coordinate system.
Absolute positioning on the child allows fixed placement within that parent.

title: Grid: Card Gallery (2→4 Columns)

description.summary: Create a responsive card gallery that shows 2 columns on small screens and 4 columns on large screens using CSS Grid.

arguments.name: .gallery { display: grid }
arguments.desc: Enable CSS Grid layout for the gallery container.

arguments.name: grid-template-columns: repeat(2, 1fr)
arguments.desc: Define two equal-width columns by default for small screens.

arguments.name: Media query at ≥1024px
arguments.desc: Switch the grid to four columns for larger screens.

returns.desc: A flexible card gallery that automatically adjusts from 2 to 4 columns depending on screen width.

web.starterHtml:
<section class="gallery">
  <article class="card">1</article>
  <article class="card">2</article>
  <article class="card">3</article>
  <article class="card">4</article>
  <article class="card">5</article>
  <article class="card">6</article>
</section>

solutionBlock.overview: CSS Grid makes it simple to create responsive galleries that adapt to different screen sizes. Use `repeat(2, 1fr)` for small screens, then switch to `repeat(4, 1fr)` inside a media query for large screens.

approaches.title: Approach — Responsive Grid Columns
approaches.prose: Define a grid with two columns by default using `grid-template-columns: repeat(2, 1fr)`. Add a `gap` for spacing. Then, at larger screen widths (min-width: 1024px), increase the columns to four by redefining the grid template.
approaches.codeHtml:
<section class='gallery'>
  <article class='card'>1</article>
  <article class='card'>2</article>
  <article class='card'>3</article>
  <article class='card'>4</article>
  <article class='card'>5</article>
  <article class='card'>6</article>
</section>
approaches.codeCss: .gallery { display: grid; gap: 1rem; grid-template-columns: repeat(2, 1fr); }\n.card { background: #222; color: #fff; border-radius: 8px; padding: 2rem; text-align: center; font-weight: 600; }\n@media (min-width: 1024px) { .gallery { grid-template-columns: repeat(4, 1fr); } }

pitfalls: Forgetting to use `repeat()` may lead to repetitive manual definitions.
Not including a `gap` can make cards stick together visually.
techniques: Use fractional units (`fr`) for flexible column sizing.
Use media queries to progressively enhance layout for larger viewports.

title: Fluid Type & Spacing with clamp()

description.summary: Make the main heading size and the container’s horizontal padding scale smoothly with the viewport using CSS clamp().

arguments.name: Fluid type with clamp()
arguments.desc: Use font-size: clamp(min, preferred, max) on the h1 to scale with viewport width while staying within bounds.

arguments.name: Fluid spacing with clamp()
arguments.desc: Use padding-inline (or left/right) with clamp() so horizontal padding grows on large screens and shrinks on small.

arguments.name: Reasonable bounds
arguments.desc: Pick sensible min/max so text isn’t tiny on phones or gigantic on desktops.

returns.desc: A hero section whose heading and side padding scale fluidly but remain readable across screen sizes.

web.starterHtml:
Fluid Headline

Scales smoothly between small and large screens.

solutionBlock.overview: Use CSS clamp() to create fluid values with safe minimum and maximum bounds. Apply it to the heading’s font-size and the hero’s horizontal padding so both scale smoothly with viewport width.

approaches.title: Approach — clamp() for Type & Padding
approaches.prose: Assign a fluid font size to the h1 using clamp(min, preferred, max). Do the same for the hero’s horizontal padding via padding-inline. This provides responsive scaling without media queries while ensuring legibility at small and large sizes.
approaches.codeHtml:
Fluid Headline

Scales smoothly between small and large screens.

pitfalls: Using an overly small min can make headings unreadable on tiny screens.
Setting an excessive max can cause overflow or awkward line breaks on large displays.
techniques: Combine vw with a base rem (e.g., 3vw + 1rem) inside clamp() for smoother scaling.
Use padding-inline to set left/right together; it mirrors automatically in RTL layouts.

title: Forms & Pseudo-classes: Focus, Invalid, Required, Helper Text

description.summary: Style an accessible form so keyboard focus is clearly visible, invalid inputs are indicated, required state is respected, and helper text is readable.

arguments.name: :focus / :focus-visible
arguments.desc: Provide a visible outline for keyboard focus. Prefer :focus-visible with a :focus fallback.

arguments.name: :invalid and :required
arguments.desc: Indicate invalid inputs with a subtle border color; don’t rely on color alone. Optional: style :required.

arguments.name: ::placeholder and :focus-within
arguments.desc: Make placeholder text lighter; highlight the label group when its input is focused using :focus-within.

returns.desc: A form where focus rings are visible, invalid fields are clearly indicated, required fields are supported, and helper text is readable.

web.starterHtml:
<form class="form" onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); alert('Form submitted!');">
  <label>
    Email
    <input type="email" required placeholder="you@example.com">
  </label>
  <small class="hint">We’ll never share your email.</small>
  <button>Submit</button>
</form>

solutionBlock.overview: Use :focus-visible (with a :focus fallback) to show an outline ring, :invalid to indicate errors, ::placeholder for lighter hint text, and :focus-within on the label to highlight the label+input group. The solution also applies nicer visual styling so it looks clearly different from the starter.

approaches.title: Approach — Focus Rings + Validation States
approaches.prose: Add a visible outline on focus using :focus-visible (and :focus as fallback). Style :invalid to adjust the border color when constraints fail. Use ::placeholder for lighter hint text. Apply :focus-within on the label to add an outline around the group. Extra visual polish (radius, stronger button) is included here so the solution preview is obviously different than the starter.

title: Transitions & Transforms: Lift on Hover

description.summary: Create a card that smoothly “lifts” on hover using transitions and transforms, with motion-respectful behavior.

arguments.name: .lift (base)
arguments.desc: Define a neutral card with padding, subtle border, and initial box-shadow.

arguments.name: .lift:hover (interaction)
arguments.desc: Apply transform (e.g., scale or translateY) and a stronger shadow on hover.

arguments.name: transition
arguments.desc: Animate both transform and box-shadow smoothly.

arguments.name: @media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce)
arguments.desc: Disable animations for users who prefer reduced motion.

returns.desc: An elevated card that animates on hover and respects reduced-motion preferences.

web.starterHtml:
Hover me

Smooth elevation and scale on hover.

solutionBlock.overview: Animate elevation by transitioning both transform and box-shadow. A tiny scale or upward translate combined with a deeper shadow gives a realistic lift effect. Always provide a reduced-motion fallback.

approaches.title: Approach — Transition + Hover Transform
approaches.prose: Set a base card with a subtle shadow. Add a transition that covers both transform and box-shadow. On :hover, scale slightly and/or translate up a couple pixels, and increase the shadow. Finally, disable transitions under prefers-reduced-motion.
approaches.codeHtml:
Hover me

Smooth elevation and scale on hover.

pitfalls: Forgetting to include box-shadow in the transition causes a snap in the shadow.
Using a large scale or translate can look jumpy; keep values subtle.
techniques: Pair transform with shadow changes for convincing depth.
Use ease or ease-out for a natural feel; keep duration around 150–250ms.

title: Theming with CSS Variables: OS Dark Mode + Manual Override

description.summary: Create a themeable panel using ONLY CSS custom properties. Define light defaults on :root, redefine the SAME variables for OS dark mode via @media (prefers-color-scheme: dark), then add a manual override using html.theme-dark that is declared AFTER the media query so it always wins. Toggle by manually adding class="theme-dark" to the <html> element (no JavaScript).

arguments.name: :root variables (light defaults)
arguments.desc: Define theme tokens on :root: --bg, --text, --surface, --accent, --border, --accent-contrast.

arguments.name: OS dark mode variables
arguments.desc: Use @media (prefers-color-scheme: dark) to redefine those SAME variables for dark mode.

arguments.name: Manual override wins by order
arguments.desc: Add html.theme-dark AFTER the media query. It must set the dark values again, so it overrides OS settings.

arguments.name: Components use ONLY variables
arguments.desc: Inside .panel and .btn, do not hard-code any colors. All colors must come from variables.

returns.desc: A panel and button fully themeable via variables, adapting to OS theme, and forceable to dark by adding html.theme-dark.

web.starterHtml:
Theme Demo

This UI reads all colors from CSS variables.

solutionBlock.overview: A high-signal CSS theming setup is: tokens on :root, OS dark override via prefers-color-scheme, then an author-controlled override class declared later to win the cascade. The component must never hard-code colors—only consume tokens—so theme swaps are instant.

approaches.title: Approach — Tokens on :root + Dark Media + html.theme-dark Override
approaches.prose: Define a minimal token set (bg/text/surface/accent/border/accent-contrast). Redefine the same tokens in the dark media query for OS-level theming. Then repeat the dark token values in html.theme-dark after the media query so manual override always wins. Toggle by adding theme-dark to <html> (no JS).
approaches.codeHtml:
Theme Demo

This UI reads all colors from CSS variables.

pitfalls: Placing html.theme-dark before the media query can cause it to lose depending on order.
Hard-coding a component color (e.g., button text) breaks themeability—add a token like --accent-contrast instead.
techniques: Keep the token set small but complete (include contrast token for accent).
Use the exact same variable names across all theme layers (:root, media query, manual override).
Rely on cascade order (manual override after media query) rather than increasing specificity.
